papers.abstract: There are a number of risks to interpretability found in the growing use of complicated computational methods within the humanities. Greater attention needs to be given to the format and presentation of the underlying data and the interpretation of any data-derived results. Visually appealing graphic renderings of data, high classification accuracy and confidence scores, and impressive summary statistics can be rhetorically structured to appeal to preconceived notions and commonplace understandings. While making arguments from the summary of significant features might be permissible in some applications of what is now commonly called data science, humanistic uses of computation put forward in the service of academic arguments require much greater access to and grounding in interpretable digital objects. When features are derived from text, these underlying features need to be shown and interpreted. This essay argues that claims made on behalf of computational models need to be evaluated and warranted by a set of shared assumptions and the ability to test and verify that the data are indeed comprehensible according to the norms of the shared interpretative community.

events.Text: There are a number of risks to interpretability found in the growing use of complicated computational methods within the humanities. Greater attention needs to be given to the format and presentation of the underlying data and the interpretation of any data-derived results.

Visually appealing graphic renderings of data, high classification accuracy and confidence scores, and impressive summary statistics can be rhetorically structured to appeal to preconceived notions and commonplace understandings. While making arguments from the summary of significant features might be permissible in some applications of what is now commonly called data science, humanistic uses of computation put forward in the service of academic arguments require much greater access to and grounding in interpretable digital objects. events.Main Action: Evaluations and Warranties Needed for Claims

Purpose: Ensuring Robustness and Reliability of Model-Based Conclusions
Results: Improved Clarity and Reduced Errors in Applications
Analysis: Addressing Challenges Related to Text Complexity and Metric Standardization

papers.abstract: Katherine Bode theorizes a new approach to “data rich” literary history, in which the researcher constructs a “a scholarly edition of a literary system” pairing annotated data with a critical apparatus. Bode challenges the rhetoric around distant reading, arguing it recapitulates the historical oversights of New Criticism. A World of Fiction comprises a book and paired database which apply this framework to the fiction published in nineteenth-century Australian newspapers. Bode's investigation advances new ideas about the gender of Australian fiction authors, the networks of influence among provincial and metropolitan newspapers, and the national character of fiction in the period. A World of Fiction is an important intervention in conversations about computational literary-historical analysis, as well as around the construction and use of digitized historical archives.

events.Text: Katherine Bode theorizes a new approach to “data rich” literary history, in which the researcher constructs a “a scholarly edition of a literary system” pairing annotated data with a critical apparatus.

Primary Object: a scholarly edition of a literary system
Secondary Object: pairing annotated data with a critical apparatus

Purpose: address historical oversights in New Criticism

events.Text: Bode's investigation advances new ideas about the gender of Australian fiction authors, the networks of influence among provincial and metropolitan newspapers, and the national character of fiction in the period.

Primary Object: networks of influence among provincial and metropolitan newspapers

Purpose: explore and understand the gender roles, newspaper influences, and national characteristics across the specified period
Implications: further studies using similar methodologies could build upon Bode's work, potentially refining analyses or exploring long-term impacts of media influence on literary works

events.Text: A World of Fiction is an important intervention in conversations about computational literary-historical analysis, as well as around the construction and use of digitized historical archives.

Context: around the construction and use of digitized historical archives
Purpose: highlighting its importance in these academic discourses
Results: recognition of its role in facilitating dialogue between experts
Analysis: insights into the effectiveness of interventions in bridging disciplinary divides
Challenge: potential discrepancies in methodologies employed across studies
Ethical: considerations surrounding access vs veracity in historical data representation
Implications: long-term benefits for fostering interdisciplinary collaboration
Contradictions: disagreements concerning varying standards in digital archiving practices
